doc.title: Sho-Time: Resilience in standout export-oriented value stocks
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/MS/Japan Equity Strategy Sho-Time Resilience in standout export-oriented value stocksJapan Equity Strategy Sho-Time Resilie_2025-08-28

processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/MS

passages.text: August 28, 2025 12:26 PM GMT
Japan Equity Strategy | Japan

The near-term focus is whether markets will continue to endorse the US soft- landing scenario. As long as the market- implied US terminal rate remains at or above the neutral rate—around \(3\%\) —export- oriented value stocks should stand out for their stability.

Stability of export- oriented value stocks: As long as the US terminal rate priced in by markets stays above the \(3\%\) neutral level, a firm USD/JPY supports these names. No serious US recession pricing: Despite dovish signals at Jackson Hole, the yen did not strengthen. Fed Chair's stance: Inflation remains key to the dual mandate; fading dovish Fed expectations and rising US rates & USD/JPY are tailwinds for export- oriented value stocks. Relative advantage: As long as markets endorse the US soft- landing scenario, export- oriented value stocks with solid earnings support are likely to be favored. Near- term watchpoints: LDP's Upper House election review (Sept 2), US August jobs report (Sept 5), and August CPI (Sept 11).
Exhibit 1: Relative return of exportoriented stocks to domestic demand oriented stocks and USD/JPY

Notes: Inverse based on TOPIX500; export-oriented stocks (autobbles & transportation equipment, steel & nonferrous metals, machinery, electric appliances & precision instruments, and commercial & wholesale trade), domestic-demand stocks (foods, construction & materials, IT & services/others, transportation & logistics, and retail trade); figures since October 2022 onward and based on forecasts for next FY. Source: Bloomberg, FactSet, QUICK Workstation, INDB, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 2: Pricing of the US terminal rate vs. surprises in the US labor market
Source: Bloomberg, FactSet, QUICK Workstation, INDB, Morgan Stanley Research
MORGAN STANLEY MUFG SECURITIES CO., LTD +

As long as the US terminal rate stays above the neutral level \((3\%)\) , a firm USD/JPY should continue to support export- oriented value stocks: Analyst revisions are improving, especially for exporters, but TOPIX remains range- bound. At Jackson Hole, Fed Chair Powell acknowledged rising inflation and weakening jobs report, and stated the Fed would act quickly if layoffs or unemployment rise. Our US economics team sees a lower hurdle for rate cuts. Despite the Fed's dovish tone, USD/JPY held firm—positive for Japanese equities.

Despite narrowing rate differentials between Japan and the US, many investors see the resilience of USD/JPY as a puzzle: As highlighted in our report Sho- Time: Japan's Role as a Stabilizer in Global Equity Portfolios (21 Aug 2025), the market continues to price the US terminal rate near the neutral level of \(3\%\) , reflecting limited recession concerns. This suggests that investors expect Fed rate cuts to support growth, rather than signal a downturn—helping keep USD/JPY firm. Unless US labor data deteriorates meaningfully, this dynamic should continue to support export- oriented value stocks.

Fed Chair Powell emphasized that inflation is key to achieving the dual mandate. If dovish expectations for the Fed fade and US rates and USD/JPY rise, export- oriented value stocks are likely to gain relative strength: While the Jackson Hole meeting was initially seen as dovish, Powell later noted that a longer- run inflation rate of 2 percent as most consistent with Fed's dual- mandate goals, committing to this target is a key factor helping keep longer- term inflation expectations well anchored. If CPI stabilizes toward \(2\%\) , rate cuts toward the neutral level may be justified. However, if inflation remains sticky or shows signs of reacceleration—such as from tariffs—dovish expectations may be reassessed. In that case, rising US rates and USD/JPY could further support export- oriented value stocks.

Based on Chair Powell's remarks at the Jackson Hole meeting, our US economics team now expects the Fed to begin cutting rates as early as the September FOMC. The new forecast calls for a total of 50bps in cuts by end- 2025, followed by 25bps cuts each quarter in 2026, bringing the target range to 2.75- 3.00%. This marks a revision from the previous outlook, which anticipated rate cuts starting in March 2026 and a target range of 2.50- 2.75% by 2026 year- end.

Even if the Fed cuts rates by 25bps at the September FOMC, in line with our US economics team's outlook, dovish expectations could fade depending on how the Fed communicates its stance. In that case, rising US rates and USD/JPY could provide additional tailwinds for Japan's export- oriented value stocks (see Exhibit 13 for stock list).

Earnings from major US tech firms did not trigger risk- off sentiment in Japan's equity market, particularly among AI- related stocks: NVIDIA's earnings (announced on August 27) beat market expectations for both revenue and EPS. Although its shares briefly fell by \(5\%\) in after- hours trading, Japan's market on August 28 saw active buying in names such as SoftBank Group, which has ties to NVIDIA, and Fujikura, a key player in AI infrastructure. Overall, NVIDIA's results did not spark a risk- off move centered on AI- related stocks in Japan.
A key focus going forward is whether markets will continue to endorse the US soft

In Japan, attention is on the LDP's post- election review due September 2, with focus on whether Secretary- General Moriyama or Prime Minister Ishiba will announce their resignation. If so, the timeline for a leadership race and potential change in administration could quickly take shape. As noted in Sho- Time: A New Game Begins, past cases suggest an LDP leadership election would likely follow within 2–3 weeks. Even if the current administration remains, the ruling coalition still lacks a majority in both houses, requiring cooperation with opposition parties on economic policy. Expansionary fiscal measures could benefit bank stocks via a steeper yield curve, though short- term correction risks remain, as bank stocks appear to have overshot market- implied BOJ rate expectations.
Exhibit 3: TOPIX cumulative return from 2024 and EPS and P/E contribution factors
Source: Bloomberg, FactSet, QUICK Workstation, I-N Information Systems, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 4: TOPIX 500 EPS analyst revisions

Note: Export-oriented sectors: Autos & Transp. Equip., Steel & Nonferrous, Machinery, Elec. & Precision, Trading & Wholesale. Domestic-demand sectors: Food, Construction & Materials, InfoComm & Other Services, Transport & Logistics, Retail (per TSE 17-sector classification). Basis: FY+1 forecasts. Period: Since Jan 2019. Source: Bloomberg, FactSet, QUICK Workstation, INDB, Morgan Stanley Research
Exhibit 13: Export-oriented value stocks with solid earnings support

Overweight (O). The stock's total return is expected to exceed the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Equal- weight (E). The stock's total return is expected to be in line with the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk-adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.
Not- Rated (NR). Currently the analyst does not have adequate conviction about the stock's total return relative to the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage
universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.

Underweight (U). The stock's total return is expected to be below the average total return of the analyst's industry (or industry team's) coverage universe, on a risk- adjusted basis, over the next 12- 18 months.
Unless otherwise specified, the time frame for price targets included in Morgan Stanley Research is 12 to 18 months.
Attractive (A): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months to be attractive vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below.

In- Line (I): The analyst expects the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months to be in line with the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below. Cautious (C): The analyst views the performance of his or her industry coverage universe over the next 12- 18 months with caution vs. the relevant broad market benchmark, as indicated below. Benchmarks for each region are as follows: North America - S&P 500; Latin America - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI Latin America Index; Europe - MSCI Europe; Japan - TOPIX; Asia - relevant MSCI country index or MSCI sub- regional index or MSCI AC Asia Pacific ex Japan Index.
